description:
Catchphrase is an interactive DVD game that is based on a UK TV game show.

The game comes in a square card box with a hinged lid. Inside the box contains pencils, Catch Phrase cards, a notepad and a DVD keep case. The box art refers to a 'free bonus edition' also known as the 'travel edition' of the game, this is played using the Bonus Game Cards, notepad and pencil, any number of players can play this game.

The main game, however, is played from the DVD and is for two players/teams referred to as Pink and Blue. The nature of the TV game is that the first person to press the buzzer gets to answer the question, to simulate this the game instructions specify that the two players/teams should sit apart, Blue on the left and Pink on the right, and that when either side thinks they know the answer they must grab the DVD remote and press their team's arrow button.

There are three rounds to the game;* Round 1: In this round the teams are shown a picture representing a well known phrase or saying and must guess the phrase within the twenty second time limit. There are two ways to score; + Seize the remote, press the left/right button for either the pink/blue team and then shout out the answer. If the answer is correct twenty pints are won, if the answer is incorrect then twenty points go to the other side + Within the time limit just shout out an answer. If that proves to be the correct answer when the time limit expires then ten points are won, if it is incorrect no points are awarded to the other side. The round consists of four to six questions.

  • Round 2: In this round the catchphrases divided into squares which are revealed one at a time. At the start of a question the catchphrase is worth one hundred points but this score drops by ten points as each portion of the picture is shown. As in round one players grab the remote, select their team and give their answer, if they are correct they score the remaining points, if they are incorrect the points go to the other side. This round also consists of four to six catchphrases.
  • Round 3: This is the Super Catchphrase Round. Here the board is divided into a 3x3 grid. The object is to solve a catchphrase puzzle in each cell to make a row across the board, the puzzles are shown immediately as in round one. Whichever side is in the lead at the start of the round goes first, if they succeed they win the game, if they fail the other side gets to play the round. Thinking time in this round is limited to thirty seconds for all puzzles combined.

description:
Music Hosted By Martin Kemp is an interactive quiz game featuring Martin Kemp former bassist with Spandau Ballet and successful actor. It has twelve separate games each with seven rounds, when played as a single player game only the first six rounds are available 'to stop anyone memorising all the answers'.

The game is set in an American diner with each option on the main menu taking the player to a different section, for example the game selection screen is the diner's jukebox.

The rounds in the game are:* Round 1: Popwatch. The game shows a video clip and asks a related question. All questions are shown on the screen while the clip is played and when the clip ends Martin Kemp reads the question for the player.

  • Round 2: What's That Tune? This is a single question 'Beat the iItro' type of round where the player(s) score one point for naming the song and another for naming the artist.
  • Round 3: Logical Order. There are two questions in this round in which the player is shown three pictures and is asked a question, they must place the pictures in the correct order. A typical question would show pictures of three singers and ask in what order they started their music careers, or put three artists in order of age - Martin Kemp names the people in the pictures in case the player(s) cannot identify them.
  • Round 4: Name the Singer or Band. Another two question round in which the players are shown pixellated pictures and must identify the artist(s).
  • Round 5: Multiple Choice. This round consists of ten questions each with four potential answers, typical questions would be 'X was a guitarist with which band?' or 'Which city appears in the song Put Your Hands Up for ...?'
  • Round 6: Pop the Question. Ten questions in this round too but there's no multiple choice answers to choose from.
  • Round 7: Think the Link. Two questions in which the game shows two pictures which have to be decoded to reveal a song title, the players also have to name the artist or band.

After the final round the player(s) have to swap score sheets and mark each other's answers as Martin Kemp reveals them an, just in case the game ends in a tie. each game has a tie-break question.

Some rounds will be declared to be 'Negative Scoring' which means that one point is deducted for each wrong answer, likewise some rounds may be declared 'Double Scoring', when these pop up they apply to just one team for one round. At the end of each round the player(s) are given the chance to either continue or play the round again.

Though the game is hosted by Martin Kemp he is present in voice over only and does not actually appear on screen. Players need to keep their own score and there is a score sheet on the DVD which can be printed off via a computer, instructions on where to find it are in the Extras menu which also contains an interview with Martin Kemp and details of the Golden Golf Charitable Trust which received a portion of the revenue from the sale of the game.

description:
Family Fortunes is a UK TV programme based on the US show Family Feud. In the show two teams of five, usually from the same family, are asked a series of questions which had previously been asked in a survey of one hundred members of the general public. Their objective is to give the top answers that the public gave. Each answer scores points depending on the percentage of the public who gave the same answer. If a team gives three wrong answers their opponents get a chance to 'steal' the points earned so far.

In addition to the basic round, described above, there's also a 'Double Money' round, the game ends with the winning team putting forward two members who play in a timed round to try and win the game's jackpot prize in the 'Big Money'.

The DVD game follows a similar format but makes a few changes to the mechanics of the game:

  • Round One:

    • Question One is always directed at Team A who have thirty seconds to write down what they consider to be the top five answers, during those thirty seconds Team B must write down a single answer. When the time is up the players reveal the correct answers one at a time and Team A score points for every correct answer they have no matter what order they wrote they were written down. The number of points scored for a correct answer, as in the TV show, depends on the number of people who gave the answer.
      If Team A gives five correct answers then they win the round, and the points, outright. If an answer appears which Team A did not write down then Team B have a chance to steal the points, this happens if Team B's answer is present in the answer Team A dindn't guess or any of the remaining answers.
    • Question Two is the same as Question One with the question being directed to Team B.
    • Question Three is a Viewer's Question round which is directed at both teams. This is a simple question with a choice of three answers. The teams select have only fifteen seconds of thinking/discussion time to make their choice and score fifty points if correct.

  • Round Two follows is similar to Round One:

    • This round starts with a question directed at Team B and this is followed with a question directed at Team A
    • Question Three is a Double Money question directed at Team A and Question 4 is a Double Money question directed at Team B

  • The game's final round, as in the TV show, is the Big Money round. In this DVD game the Big Money round is played by both teams, however the team in the lead at the start of the round gets to answer all five questions while the team in second/last place is only allowed to answer the first four.
    Five questions are asked and the teams must put down just one answer to each.

At the end of the Big Money round the team with the most points wins.

The game uses random DVD technology which gives a different game each time it is played. If a previously played game is presented the player(s) can select a new game via the game's menu screen. The game does not keep score for the teams, all totals are reckoned manually.

The package includes an instruction booklet and two 'wipe clean' score cards (wipe clean for felt tip pens but not for biro or pencil). The game does not feature an on-screen presenter nor does it use the music from the TV show. It does claim to feature the famous 'Uh-Uh' wrong answer sound and uses Macrovision copy protection.

description:
Tiger Woods PGA Tour is an interactive DVD game for one to four players.

This game comes in a tin box with rounded corners measuring 26.5 cm x 18cm x 5.5 cm. Inside the box are two DVDs, one for the St Andrews course and one for the TPC Sawgrass course, each in a windowed paper envelope together with a large foldout map showing one course on each side.

The game starts when the DVD is loaded and the game cycles through the licenses, title screen, welcome guide before arriving at the main menu. By default it plays 'How to play the game' instructions but these can be skipped, the main piece of information is that the game is played with just the direction arrows and the ENTER key.

Playing the game starts with the player selection screen where there are four players to choose from Tiger Woods, Colin Montgomery, Jim Furyk and John Daly - helpfully they are all wearing different coloured shirts. Each human player takes turns selecting an on-screen golfer and then choosing between the Amateur/Pro game, so it is possible for player one to use Colin Montgomery on the Pro difficulty setting while player two uses Tiger Woods on the Amateur setting. Naturally both players play the same course but on the Pro setting the wind direction and club selection have more of an impact.

Playing the game is quite straightforward. There is a fly-by of each hole together with a brief summary following this the golfer takes their place at the tee. Taking a shot is a three step process;* Step 1: Club selection. In the lower right of the screen are three clubs to choose from, the player uses the right /left direction keys to cycle between them and the ENTER button to select

  • Step 2: Direction. In front of the player there is a semi-circle of eleven direction markers with the central marker highlighted. In the upper left is an arrow showing the direction and strength of the wind, the player uses the left/right arrow keys on their remote to make an appropriate adjustment to the direction of the shot and ENTER to select it

  • Step 3: Taking the shot. Once the first two steps have been completed the view shifts to show the golfer side-on and a circular power meter with a rising power bar appears in the upper right. The player uses the ENTER button on the remote to stop the power bar at an appropriate point depending on the distance to the pin.

The same process is repeated for all shots apart from putting on the green when there is no choice of club because the putter is the only choice. The game keeps score throughout the match and it has a faux TV commentary.

Inside is a DVD case containing a detailed manual / race guide and the DVD itself which holds sixteen races, some over hurdles but mainly on the flat. Also in the box is * a Bookies Ledger. This is a double sided record of the bets placed in each race, when the winnings have been paid the ledger is wiped clean and re-used. No cloth is provided for this.

  • Betting cards. Needed so the players also have a record of the bets they made, these are also double sided and are wiped clean before the next race

Players can bet on a horse to win, place 1st or 2nd, or place in the first three.

As players can bet as much, or as little, as they want the bookmaker then has to scale the amount shown on screen up, or down, as appropriate and pay the players.

Now That's What I Call A Music Quiz is a collection of three games based on pop music from the 1960's through to the 2000's. All games are played by one to four teams or players and there is a tutorial section for each voiced by Mark Goodier though he does not appear on screen at any point. The games available are:

  • Top 40: This is a game for one to four players or teams and the objective is to travel up a ladder from the fortieth place to the number one slot. Players do this by answering questions which are classed as easy, medium or hard and, if the player answers correctly, they move up the ranking by one, two or three positions respectively.
    Most questions are individual questions, i.e. Only the current player or team can answer but some questions allow anyone to shout out the answer. If the question is answered by the current team then they advance as normal but if an opposing player/team answers then the current team stays put.
    Some positions on the ladder are coloured red, these are the Hit or Miss squares. If a player tries to land on such a position, for example if they are two positions away and ask for a medium difficulty question, then if they get their question right they are allowed to move extra positions up the ladder however if they get the question wrong they have to move back down the ladder.
    The first player/team to reach number one must answer a random difficulty question in order to win

  • Top 20: As with the Top 40 game this can be played by up to four players or teams and it also features a ladder that runs from twenty to one. However in this game the player in control answers questions that become increasingly more difficult. The player continues answering questions until they either stick in which case they retain their position on the ladder, or until they get one wrong in which case they return to their starting position.

  • I Spy: In this game the player's select a decade from the 1960's & 1970's, 1980's, 1990's, 0r 2000's. The game then begins.
    There are five rounds and in each round a picture of a celebrity from the chosen decade is hidden behind a 3x3 grid of tiles. The current player retains control until they get a question wrong but for each correct answer a tile is removed and part of the underlying image is revealed. Any player or team can shout out the identity of the celebrity at any time, if they are right they get a point, if they are wrong they lose a point. The winner is the player or team with the most points after all five rounds have been completed.

Fingers on Buzzers is an interactive DVD game for two to four players. What makes this game different to many others is the inclusion of four individual buzzers with five buttons. These are connected by wire to an infra-red device which 'talks' to the DVD player telling it which player pushed which button.

There are two games to be played here, the short game which consists of five rounds each with six questions and the long game which has seven rounds each with eight questions. Players score one thousand points for each correct answer with the points going to the player who presses their buzzer the fastest. Guessing is to be avoided as players can lose a thousand points for an incorrect answer. At some point during the game, provided players are not tied on the same score, the game will play a 'Shake 'em Up' round where scores can be swapped or points can be stolen.

Scores are announced at the end of the round and if there is a tie at the end of the game.

The rounds vary considerably in content from basic spelling and mental arithmetic, a whack-a-mole like round where the player has to press the appropriate coloured button when a specific picture appears, identifying objects in pixelated images or a person from a sound clip. All questions and instructions are fully voiced throughout the game.

Trivial Pursuit DVD Game: Star Wars Saga Edition is an interactive DVD game. This game is a two player version of Trivial Pursuit DVD: Star Wars Saga Edition which comes with a full Trivial Pursuit board etc and is for more players. This game comes in a black keep case sized box with predominantly silver writing that is enclosed in a card sleeve. The box is four cm deep and opens like a chest, a plastic DVD mount has been glued to the inside of the lid while in the base are recesses for the two dice and the stack of question cards.

There are many similarities between the two games, both games come with two DVDs containing twenty pre-planned quizzes and the question cards look identical apart from the colouring of the game's name. The question categories are also identical, being:

  • Blue - The Cantina: these questions are about specific scenes, cameo roles and alien races.
  • Pink - The Force: this features scenes in which the Force is used or referred to.
  • Yellow - Heroes, Villains & Scoundrels: the title says it all.
  • Brown - The Saga: these questions are about the movie plots, sub plots and story arcs.
  • Green - A Galaxy Far Away: a category devoted to the towns, cities, planets and galaxies of the Star Wars universe - at least the movie versions.
  • Orange - Wildcard: a sort of miscellaneous group

Without having both games available for direct comparison it is not possible to say whether the games use exactly the same questions, however given that both games have the same title and menu screens plus the credits of this game are dated 2005 it does seem probable that this game is a reworking of the big box game.

Gameplay here differs from the big box version of the game in two ways. The first difference is that there are two dice for the player to roll, one die determines whether the player answers a DVD question or a card question while the second determines the question category. The second difference is the scoring system because instead of moving tokens around a board the game has been adapted to use a scorecard system. Both players have a card showing a scoring grid and a cover card that, well, covers it. As questions are answered the cover card is moved to reveal a column on the score card. There are three levels of difficulty to the game so after revealing six, nine or twelve columns the player can attempt the 'For The Win' final question.

The game starts with the selection of the number of players; 1-4, and a short intro video showing the audience sitting around the central empty seat.

There is no time limit that requires an answer before it runs out.

There are two safety levels at 10.000 and 100.000, and 15 questions to the maximum sum of 3 Million (virtual) SEK. Three lifelines are available per game: 50:50, 'ask the audience' and 'ask a friend'. If a player manages to answer all questions correctly and win the virtual millions, they are shown a code that lets them participate in a real competition via a one-time mail-in coupon for a vacation trip for four persons to Spain, visiting the Universal Studios Mediterranea resort. This coupon was only available in the DVD release of the game, and the competition ended in mid 2005.

The game is based on the TV Show's format. I has four rounds. Each round starts with a short introduction from Fearne Cotton who also presents each round's help section. Points earned in rounds one, two and three may earn lifelines in the final round. The rounds are:

  1. Auditions: These represent the TV show's regional auditions in which the player(s) judge three acts based on clips from the show. Two points are earned if the player's assessment matches the judges.

  2. Boot Camp: This round asks the player(s) three questions based on music knowledge and X Factor trivia. At the start of the round each player is assigned one of the following question categories Groups; 14-24 year old girls; 14-24 year old boys; 25 year old and over. Questions generally show a clip of a song being sung by X Factor contestants and the player is asked a related question such as "Who was the original artist?"; "Name the song?" and so on. If the question is answered correctly the player is asked a bonus question such as "Name the best selling group of all time?"; "Which city did the 2003 finalist X come from?"; "Name the first UK hit single/album by XXXX?". All questions are multiple choice with three possible answers.

  3. Judges' Homes: This is a timed round of three questions each worth five points. Despite the title the questions are about X Factor presenters and contestants not the places they live. Questions include pixelated pictures of presenters and acts that slowly become clearer; clips of acts from the TV show that have to be named; and presenter related questions such as which acts that they managed etc.

  4. Live Shows. This is the main round of the game. The player(s) are asked five questions each and can choose from Easy, Medium and Hard categories. The categories are worth one, two and three weeks (points) respectively which represents the ten week road to the TV Final.

description:
Richard Hammond's Top Gear Stunt Challenge is a one or two player game, or as the game puts it 'Billy No Mates' and 'Head to Head', and it is a series of silly mini games with lots of video clips rather than the usual DVD quiz. The game invites players to select a team from Team Hammond; Team May; Team Clarkson and Team Stig and then the games begin. The game keeps score and everything is explained by Richard Hammond, the challenges are;* The Let's Not Blow Up Richard Hammond game: There are five white vans lined up on the Top Gear runway. Richard hides in one of them and one team attempts to blow up the empty vans. In preparation for this round the teams bid for how many empty vans they think they can blow up, the team that loses out in the bidding secretly selects the van Richard will be in.

Points are awarded for selecting the chosen number of empty vans and not blowing up Richard, points are lost if Richard is toasted.

  • Crock And Roll: 30 Years Of Top Gear. Here Richard shows a TV clip from an old Top Gear episode and the team/player has a limited time in which to guess the year. If they fail to answer within the time limit additional clues are given but the number of points is reduced. Teams answer questions alternately.

  • Dashboard Reference: This is a spot the difference round where teams take turns to answer. A dashboard is shown for a short time, fifteen seconds or thereabouts, and then there is an interval where Richard does something like driving an off-road car in a race with a motor bike - a clever distraction to wipe the image of the dashboard from the players' minds, after which the dashboard is shown once again but something subtle will have changed.

  • Skittle Powersliding: The Stig powerslides one of fifteen cars round a corner and attempts to knock over man-sized skittles in the process. Teams are shown some basic statistics about the car being used and guess how many skittles will be knocked over.

  • Bunch Of Stunts: This is a multiple choice quiz round where the questions are based on Top Gear stunts.
    For example Top Gear once featured a race between a Bugatti Veron and a Eurofighter, the question asked is "The Bugatti's top speed is 252mph. What is the Eurofighter's?

  • Carabungee: This starts with a caravan suspended from a crane by bungee rope(s). When dropped the caravan falls to earth but stops well before it hits the earth. Teams take turns to add domestic objects ranging from a safe to a microwave in an attempt to get the caravan to fall further without hitting the ground.

  • The Golden Anorak: This is billed as the quiz bit for geeks, teams take turns to answer ten questions. Example questions are;

    • This car weighs xxxx kg, does this car weigh more or less?
    • As above but substitute cost for weight
    • Where is this car built?
    • In which film does the featured car stunt appear?

description:
Nostalgia is another DVD quiz game this time based on events from the 1960's onwards. There are twelve games on the DVD, six multiplayer games and six single player games, in each case the objective is the same and that is to score as many points as possible over seven newspaper themed rounds.

Scoring is done manually with a pen and a piece of paper and a score sheet is available on the DVD in .pdf format. Teams must select a name and an icon before the game begins as throughout the quiz the icon will be used to indicate bonus questions some of which could score double points for a correct answer while others can lose the team points for an incorrect answer.

All players/teams see the same questions on screen and record their answers on separate score sheets, the format of the rounds is as follows:* Round 1: Time Trivia. Following a video clip the players may be asked "Who was the next American president?", or "This took place in xxxxxx, on what sea does xxxxxx lie?" as well as the usual "What year was this?"

  • Round 2: Blast From The Past. The players are shown a fragmented picture and must identify the person portrayed, just three questions in this round.
  • Round 3: Multiple Choice. Twelve quick questions each with four possible answers.
  • Round 4: Who Said What?. This round has two audio clips and the players have to identify the speaker
  • Round 5: The Order Of Time. Two questions in which the teams are shown four pictures and must put them in the correct order.
  • Round 6: Question Time. Twelve quick questions ranging from subjects as diverse as US politics, UK music, computer games and technology, television and fashion since the 1960's.
  • Round 7: Read All About It. Players are shown the front page of a newspaper and must answer question on it

After each round players are given the opportunity to replay it or continue.

All questions are spoken as well as appearing as on-screen text

If the scores are tied at the end of a game a single tie-break question is asked. The first person/team to answer correctly wins, if neither side answers correctly then the side whose answer is closest wins.

description:
The Price Is Right is a television show that started in America in the mid 1950's and since then the game has been remade in over forty countries. This game is based on the UK show and is presented by Joe Pasquale who hosted the show in 2006/7.

There are two modes of depending on the number of players, there is no single player option;* 3 or 4 Players: This plays just like the television show. + Round 1: The Pricing Round. Players are shown an object and must guess it's price from a range of options without 'going over'. All players choose from the same selection of prices so going first is an advantage.
The winner of the first round then has a chance at a 'Super Game' where they can win an additional prize before going on to the grand final. This process is repeated until only one player is left - that player has lost. 

Super games are mini games played for an additional prize, typically players are asked to select the highest/lowest items or the items that have the same price from a selection.

+ Round 2: The Big Wheel Round: The 'Big Wheel' has segments with values up to 100. The remaining players spin th wheel to get the highest score without exceeding 100. The winning player gets to play the Showcase Final.

+ Round Three: The Showcase Final. Before playing the final round the remaining contestant plays a simple mini game to find out how accurate their final bid must be. With that decided the player is then shown a range of items from garden features to motorbikes, from holidays to furniture and guesses the combined value selecting a price from the options offered without 'going over'. If successful they win the game, either way it's Game Over and the credits roll.

In the Pricing Round and in its Super Games players are shown a computer generated representation of the item to be priced but in the Showcase Final they are shown a filmed sequence with models and the real thing.
  • Joe's Two Player Challenge: a player must win thee pricing games in order to progress to the big wheel round. If the player wins the Big Wheel round they are straight through to the Showcase Final, if they lose then they must win another pricing game before they can try again.

On the inside cover is a text-in competition for a cash prize.

description:
This DVD game is a quiz based on Big Brother (UK) trivia.

There are two ways to play the game, single player or multiplayer. In the single player game the player is asked a series of twenty random questions after which they are given their score.

The multiplayer game is played over eight rounds where each round represents a week in the house with the winner being the player with the most votes (aka points). While playing this game the players choose a housemate as an avatar and are referred to my the housemate's name and not their own. After each round the game reveals which player has the most votes.
In Weeks One, Two and Three each housemate is asked three random questions themed as a variety of different tasks;
- Big Brother's Trivia: A simple multiple choice question
- Diary Room Demons: Here players listen to a clip and guess who is speaking
- Headline Grabbers: A Big Brother related newspaper page is shown with a word of the headline blacked out and platers must guess the missing word
- Catchphrase: Some housemates had a catchphrase but who had what?
- Missing Housemates: A picture of housemates is shown where one 'mate has been hidden by pixellation, who is it?

In Week Four each player has to answer three quick-fire questions, only five second per question to answer. The questions can be from one of two categories;
- Matching Pairs: Pictures of two housemates are shown and the player has to answer Yes if they were in the Big Brother house at the same time, otherwise they answer No
- Name The Housemate: After seeing a housemate's picture the player must identify them correctly.

In Week Five watch player's watch a clip and decide what happens next.
Week Six is called Rucks and Rows, players watch two video clips each and decide what the argument was about in each clip.
Week Seven is the Name The Year round, this is the only round where there are clues available but using a clue means a reduced score for a correct answer.
The final week is Week Eight, The Eviction. The players are shown a full set of housemates from a series and take turns to place them into the order they were evicted, an incorrect answer costs one hundred votes.

After Week Eight players are evicted in ascending order which means the last remaining player has the highest score and the the winner.

All questions are multiple choice and are spoken by an announcer who never appears on screen. The game keeps score so no pencil and paper is necessary.

Telly Addicts: Multi-Player Family Edition is a family game based on the UK TV show 'Telly Addicts'. It is a quiz about television shows for one or two players/teams and there is an option to select whether each team is playing as an adult or as a child.

The game is played over seven rounds and during the game each team will receive a bonus question, there's no need for pen and paper to keep score as the game does this automatically and shows the score at the end of each round.

Round One: Screen Test. In this round there are six TV screens shown and behind each is a picture or a video clip and a related question. Players take it in turns to select a screen and answer a question, they get one point for each correct answer.

Round Two: TV Ties. This time each player gets just one set of themed questions. The first question is a picture question showing characters from a show and the player must name the character that is missing. Following this are two related questions, each correct answer scores one point giving a maximum of three points for the round.

Round Three: Classic Clips. Again there's just one set of questions per player with each correct answer scoring one point giving a maximum of three points for the round. After watching a TV clip the players are asked related questions, one is observational, one is about the show and one is about the character.

Round Four: Odd One Out. Slightly different format to this round but still up to three points at stake. Players are shown pictures of four characters from a show, say Del Boy; Rodney; Uncle Albert and Trigger from 'Only Fools and Horses', and they are given a clue to identify the odd one out. If the player answers correctly straight away they score three points, if they answer incorrectly they score zero. However there are two additional clues on offer. Taking each clue reduces the number of points scored for a correct answer by one point.

Round Five: Theme Tunes. Simply identify a theme tune from a sound clip.

Round Six: Guess The Show. Guess The Show. Identify the TV show from the clues given by members of the public. As with Round Four there are additional clues available but they reduce the number of points for a correct answer

Round Seven: Spotlight. Each player is asked three questions in succession and is given only ten seconds to answer each one.

At the end of the game Noel announces the winner. If there is a tie then the game will ask a tiebreaker question.

description:
Raven is a DVD game based on BBC Scotland's TV show which ran from 2002 to 2010 in the UK and which was later revived for a short run in 2017 to 2018.

The original TV show was hosted by James Mackenzie who presents this DVD. In the show a group of children faced a series of tasks to become 'The Ultimate Warrior' and the game follows a similar format.

The game can be played as a single player game or as a multiplayer game for two, three or four players. In the multi player game each player is asked two questions to determine their spirit character whereas in the single player game the player simply chooses between the two characters offered.
Once the characters have been chosen the next step is to choose a route. There are three routes to choose from;
- The Path Of The Demon: Four levels. Difficulty level three
- The Path Of The Wizard: Six levels. Difficulty level six
- The Path Of Nevar: Eight levels. Difficulty level nine.

Each path consists of a number of mini games and puzzles. Players start with a number of feathers which are effectively lives because when they are all lost the game is over. Players receive gold rings as a reward for successfully completing a task and seven of these rings can be used to buy back one feather, in some tasks there are additional rings that can be discovered and added to the player's total.

In the multiplayer game the players arrive at a mini game and play it in turns but each game can be slightly different. For example in the mini game Burning Battlements player one completes their turn, then player two and so on whereas in the game Demon Square a question is asked and the players take turns to answer it, then the next question is asked until all questions have been asked.

Some of the mini games are:
- Enchanted Stream: To win two gold rings the player must reassemble a broken bridge by clicking on a selection of pieces in the correct order.
- Spider Tunnel: There the player has to navigate a maze, collect gold rings and avoid spiders.
- Demon Causeway: The player and the demon move alternately and the objective is to cross a grid without being caught. The reward is one gold ring but there are other rings hidden under the tiles of the grid.
- Riddle Bridge: After the magic book has read a riddle the player is presented with a bridge of letters, the task is to select the correct letters from each step of the bridge and get to the other side by completing the word that answers the riddle.
- Demon Square: The Wisdom Tree asks a series of questions to which the answers are either True or False. For each correct answer the player advances one square. Two incorrect answers ends the game
- Serpent's Eye: This is a shooting game where the player has three attempts to hit a target
- Burning Battlements: The player uses a siege catapult to douse three fires with water bombs
- Dwarf Mine: This is a memory game. The player is shown four symbols before they enter the mine. These symbols are on props which must be removed in order to go deeper in the mine, removing the wrong props will cause the roof to collapse. >br> - Way of the Warrior: This is the final game where the player has to navigate a path and avoid traps. There are three stages to complete and if successful the player will enter the portal to the Last Stand.

John Francome's Day At The Races is a family DVD game based on betting on the outcome of pre-recorded real horse races it is very similar to John Francome's Night At The Dogs

The game comes in a box which contains a DVD in a keep case; £80,000 of 'fun money' money in four denominations, a pad of betting slips; four pencils; a wipe-clean bookmaker's slate and a wipe-clean pen; and a manual. The DVD contains sixteen races all filmed at UK race courses.

At the start of the game players nominate the most capable of their number as the bookie, this person accepts bets, hands out winnings and has the final word in any dispute. Players are given £6,000 in game money to bet with, they then load the DVD and watch John Francome introduce the game and optionally explain it in detail for those who have not played it before.

When a race is selected from the race menu the DVD shows a race sheet with the names of the runners, their odds and their form or previous race history over which John Francome's voice can be heard giving his tips for the upcoming race. The nominated bookie writes the names and the odds on the bookmaker's slate and takes bets from the players.
Players are allowed two bets per race, the minimum bet is £100 and all bets are in multiples of £100 to keep the maths simple. There are eight runners in each race and just two types of bet are allowed, betting on a horse to win or an each-way bet where the punter bets that a horse will finish first, second or third.
When all bets have been made the DVD remote is used to press the on-screen 'Ready To Race' button and the film of the race is shown with full commentary and a replay of the last few seconds as the winner crosses the line. The game then announces the winners and, as an aid to the bookie, it states what the return of a successful £100 bet would be.

Also on the DVD are;
- Extra betting slips - there's a .pdf file on the DVD which can be printed when the betting slip pad is exhausted
- John Francome's Racing Funnies - a selection of anecdotes
- A summary of racing terms

The Interactive Football DVD Quiz Game is a football quiz which comes in a card keep case inside a card sleeve.

This is a five round football quiz for one or two teams/players. Players can choose between two types of game, the League Game and the Cup Game, both have five rounds but there are twice as many questions in the League Game. At the end of the game the player with the highest score wins, in the event of a tie there is a sudden death round where the first player to make a mistake loses.
During the game there may be 'pop-ups' which could be a bonus that doubles the points scored in a round or a penalty which loses one point for every incorrect answer in a round.

  • Round One: Following a short video clip there are two multiple choice questions.
  • Round Two: A video clip is paused part way through and players must say what happened next. This is not a multiple choice question and there's nothing sophisticated here, the player literally says what they think happens next then continues the quiz where the correct answer is revealed. The game then asks 'Did you answer correctly?' and expects an honest answer.
  • Round Three: A speed round - players are shown a question and four images which must be ranked in the correct order.
  • Round Four: The 'Name The Player' round. A blurred picture is revealed one tile at a time, answering quickly scores more points. When the player thinks they have the answer the click on the on-screen 'Reveal' button and are told the answer at which point hey are again asked 'Did you answer correctly?'
  • Round Five: Three multiple choice questions to be answered against the clock.

The quiz is hosted by Jonathan Pearce, a veteran sports broadcaster, who introduces the quiz as a whole and explains each round; there's an interview with him in the DVD Extras section.

Bingo is a simple family bingo game.

This game comes with no bingo cards, the organiser has to print these off from the company web site. Once that has been done and everyone playing has a card and a marker the game can begin. description:
The Ultimate Pop Quiz is a quiz for up to four players/teams played over five rounds (called stages in this game).

The five rounds are:

  • Stage One: Beat The Bouncers
  • Stage Two: Get Gigging
  • Stage Three: The Stage Is Set
  • Stage Four: The Stadium Tour
  • Stage Five: The Backstage Pass

The questions get harder as the player(s) progress through the stages. Each stage may contain the following types of question:

  • General Knowledge: Who is engaged to who?, who joined/left this band? and so on.
  • Guess Who: Identify an artist or group from a distorted image.
  • Sounds Like A Hit: Identify the song.
  • Chart Positions: Two songs by the same artist but which rose highest?
  • Wax Lyrical: The question may give a line from a song and asks which song is it from, or it could ask something like, "This song is about going on holiday but where to?"
  • The Gallery: These questions show pictures and ask a related question.

In each round players take turns to answer timed multiple choice questions. The faster a player answers a question the more points they score, answering a question in less than five seconds scores five points while answering in less than 10 seconds scores two points and answering in less than 15 seconds scores just one point.

20 points are needed to progress to Stage Five and, to beat the game, a player must score five Stage Five points.

For each question the player will have a 'Rescue' option which will either swap the question for another or it will grant them extra time to answer, however a player can only use this option three times per game.

Should there be a tie at the end of Stage Five, the game will enter a sudden death round.

There is no guest to host the quiz so the instructions and the questions have to be read as there is no voiceover. The game keeps score so there is no need for pencils and pieces of paper.

description:
This is a family game for two teams, a red team and a blue team. The game is hosted by Suggs, the lead singer of the band Madness, who were very big in the '80s. He not only introduces the game; he also reads all of the questions as well as the in-game instructions.

There are three game formats available:

  • The Quick Game - the first to 25 points wins
  • The Short Game - played to 50 points
  • The Long Game - ends at 80 points

All questions are timed and must be answered within 10 seconds. A standard question will score five points if answered correctly and within the allowed time but before playing a question, a team can opt to gamble.

There are three kinds of gamble available; a correctly answered can either score more bonus points, or it can double the team's score (the downside being that if the question is not answered correctly the team's score is wiped out), or it can steal points from the other team.

The types of question are:

  • Which Year? Typically the team is shown a picture of an artist or a personality and then asked when did a particular event take place. The player picks a year from the four on offer.
  • Fact or Crap: A simple true/false question.
  • Missing Lyrics: A famous line from a famous song is shown with one word missing; the player selects their answer from a choice of four.
  • Picture This: Here the picture shown to the team looks a bit like a colour negative and the team has to identify who it is.
  • Suggs Says: Best described as questions that do not fit into the other categories and which are sometimes based on quotes.
  • A.K.A.: These are questions about the real names of famous people from the '80s.
  • Odd One Out: Example question could be "Which of these songs was not a hit for X in the 80s?" or "Which band did X not play for?"
  • 1 Hit Wonders: Typically "Who had a hit with this song?" or sometimes "This song was a hit for which of these singers?"

The game keeps score so there is no need for pencils and pieces of paper.

description:
There are two discs in this title, one for horse racing and one for greyhound racing. Whereas most DVD games of this type use pre-recorded live races, this product uses virtual races.

The game is for one to four players who compete over matches of four, six, eight or 10 races to see who can make the most, or lose the least, money. All players bet in every race and the game calculates the winnings.

When a race is introduced, each player in turn picks a runner, after which they select their bet which can be either: "Bet To Win" or "Bet Each Way." Each option comes with a fixed range of stakes. When all players have made their bets, there's a 3-2-1 countdown after which the virtual race, complete with commentary, is run.

After the race the game announces the winnings and loses after which it proceeds to the next race.

This interactive DVD is for fans of the football club Manchester United. In addition to video clips of past glories and virtual tour there is a single player quiz and a multiplayer quiz.

The single player 'Fan Test' is a 20-question quiz where each question is classed as an individual round. It is also an unusual quiz as it ends as soon as the player gets a question wrong. When replayed, the questions are not in the same order so the questions that the player previously answered correctly may not appear.

The multiplayer quiz is for up to four players. After answering a starter question correctly, players can choose a bonus question valued at one, two or three points. The game ends when a player reaches twenty five points.

There are some light hearted 'spot the ball' questions while other questions are for people who really know their statistics; for example, being shown a team lineup for a 2002/3 league match and being asked which player is missing.

This game is a single player arena fighting game with robots.

There are two parts to the game. The first part of the game are the Qualification Bouts, where the player is shown two robots from which they make their selection. The two robots then fight and, if the player's choice wins, they win a token. This continues until the player has accumulated four tokens.

description:
The first DVD release of the movie Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone was released with a 2nd special feature disc which included interactive games. The special features disc takes the player to an interactive menu of the Great Hall with selectable icons relating to the movie.

Selecting Harry's owl Hedwig takes the player to the brick entrance to Diagon Ally, where they must select the bricks in the order shown in the movie to enter. After entering the player is then given the choice of going to the Owl Emporium, Olivander's Wands, or the Wizarding Bank. At the bank the player will be told to find a key in the previous menu, the other two other locations will let the user make a selection of owls and wands to learn about them.

Selecting the candles lets the player go on an interactive tour of the Gryffindor common room, and the Great Hall from the movie.

Selecting the wand takes the player to a selection of four classrooms that each have corresponding extras and a clip of the classroom's teacher from the movie. The potions classroom includes a potion-making minigame.

Selecting the sorting hat gives a selection of the four houses which gives information on the selected house.

Selecting the books takes the player to the library where they can select books and get different extras, such as concept art, and clips from the movie.

Selecting the cat takes the player to a selection of the quidditch balls or Fang. Choosing the Golden Snitch starts a mini-game where the player has to catch the snitch to learn to more information about the ball. Selecting Fang takes the player on an interactive tour of Hagrids Hut.

Selecting the Lantern plays interviews with the movie's cast.

There is no in-game scoring system and the questions are not multiple choice so players will need pencils and paper to write down their answers; printable scoresheets are included on the DVD. There are no video sequences but most questions do have a still photograph. There is no voice acting or in-game music.

There are five rounds to each question category, the categories are:

  • Which Bond
  • Which Film

It is up to the player(s) to decide whether they are playing as individuals or in teams and it is recommended that a question master is appointed, their duties being advancing to the next question when players are ready and adjudicating over the inevitable disputed answers.

description:
Scene It? Jr. Edition is one of a series of games in the Scene It? series. This version of the game features questions based on movies, TV, music, and sports.

This is a boxed game that is played on the standard Scene It? 'flex-time' game board such that when there's not enough time/interest to play a full game it can be folded, reducing its size so that a short game can be played instead. The player(s) must travel around the board to the Final Cut area where they must answer an All Play To Win challenge. If they are successful, they win the game, if not they move to the outer Final Cut circle and must successfully answer three DVD challenge questions to win.

The box contains a folding game board and four plastic tokens: Headphones, a beverage, a skateboard, and a cellphone.

The game is played with two dice: a six-sided die that determines how far the player moves, and an eight-sided die that determines the challenges the player will face in their travels.

  • All Play: This is a DVD challenge in which the challenge is shown on a TV and any player can answer. If two players answer simultaneously then there is a DVD Tie Breaker option.
  • My Play: This is a DVD challenge in which the challenge is shown on a TV and the player who rolls the dice can answer.
  • Buzz Card: The player selects a Buzz Card from the pack, follows the instructions, and their turn ends.
  • Trivia Challenge: Here another player draws a Trivia Challenge card and reads the question. There are three categories of trivia questions: Movies, Television, and Pop Culture, each represented by a distinct symbol on the category die. Every card has one question from each category on one side with the answers on the reverse.
  • Players Choice: Here the player selects a trivia card or DVD category of their choice.

description:
Family Fortunes: Hosted By Vernon Kaye is the second UK DVD title based on the popular television show. In the show two teams of five, usually from the same family, are asked a series of questions which had previously been asked in a survey of one hundred members of the general public. Their objective is to give the top answers that the public gave. Each answer scores points depending on the percentage of the public who gave the same answer. If a team gives three wrong answers their opponents get a chance to 'steal' the points earned so far.

There are five rounds to the game which does NOT keep score for the players, instead a score pad is provided so that teams can write down their own scores:

Round One is always directed at Team A who have thirty seconds to write down what they consider to be the top five answers; during those thirty seconds Team B must write down a single answer in the STEAL section of their score sheet. When the time is up the players reveal the correct answers one at a time and Team A score points for every correct answer they have no matter what order they wrote they were written down. The number of points scored for a correct answer, as in the TV show, depends on the number of people in the survey who gave that answer. If Team A give five correct answers then they win the round, and the points, outright.

If an answer appears which Team A did not write down then Team B have a chance to steal the points, this happens if Team B's answer is present in the answer Team A did not guess or any of the remaining answers.

Once Team A has finished its turn it is Team B’s turn.

Round Two is the "Viewer’s Question" round. Here both teams play and have just fifteen seconds to write down three answers. Either, both or neither team can score fifty points if one of their three answers matches the top answer from the public survey.

Round Three is a replay of Round One.

Round Four is the "Double Money" round, this is also a replay of Round One but, obviously, the points that can be scored or stolen are higher.

Round Five is the "Head To Head" round where each team selects their strongest player to play against the opposing team’s candidate. Five questions are asked in 25 seconds. When time is up, the answers are revealed and if the player’s answer matches the survey’s answer the player wins more points to be added to their team’s total.

description:
You Say we Pay is a DVD trivia game hosted by television presenters Richard Madeley and Judy Finnigan. It is based on the phone-in segment from the duo's Channel 4 chat show Richard & Judy. This DVD game adaption expands on the existing gameplay of You Say we Pay with additional game types and variants.

The game does not come with any written instructions; instead, the instructions appear on an in-game menu that triggers an explanation from the game's hosts depending on what is selected.

There are three game modes;

  • On Your Own: This game mode is for two to four players with each player competing for themselves
  • Two's Company: This game mode is for two to four teams of two players
  • Crowded House: This too is for two to four players but in this game mode every player gets to compete for every question

The question types are:

  • You Say We Pay The player whose turn it nominates one person who sits to one side so that they cannot see the screen and another who operates the DVD remote. The player then describes the scene/image/person on screen without using the key words in the title, and for every object in the scene the guesser guesses correctly the player earns one thousand "You See We Pay" pounds. This process is repeated for sixty seconds and is then repeated for each player.
  • The Tables Are Turned: This is only played in the "On Your Own" game mode, here Richard and Judy do the describing and the player does the guessing.
  • Acting Up: Based on Charades, this game has players mime/act the objects on screen while someone guesses what is going on.
  • Best Impressions: On screen, a picture of a celebrity is displayed. The player must try and impersonate the person while their teammates try and guess who it is.
  • Go Fetch: Household items identified within the game must be collected within a fixed period of time.

The DVD remote is used to indicate whether whatever is on screen has been guessed successfully and the game keeps track of the scores so there is no need for a pencil or paper.

This title is based on the idea that the more the brain is used the cleverer it becomes. It consists of a series of puzzles designed to test, and hopefully improve, memory, numeracy and literary skills as well as logic, spatial awareness among others.
Also on the DVD is an IQ test which the player can use to compare their score against the rest of the country. Everything is explained very clearly by James May a renowned television presenter and motoring correspondent.

Brain training consists of ten programmes each consisting of fifteen multiple choice questions from the following types;

  • Core Knowledge questions: These questions take the form "A is to B as Y is to ?"
  • Sudoku puzzles where the number of a nominated cell has to be selected
  • Dice puzzles
  • Domino puzzles which involve a sequence of some kind
  • Missing Card puzzles, a memory test where four cards are shown and then taken away and replaced and the player has to identify which card was not in the original set
  • Wordwheel where the player has to identify the word that can/cannot be made using the given letters
  • BrainDrain, this involves solving a maths equation

  • Brain Box: Here the player watches a short cartoon in which brains get into and out of a box, the objective being to keep track of the ins and outs and correctly state how many brains are in the box at the end

The game keeps a track of the player's score in these exercises and James announces the result at the end of each each test. The full IQ test uses the different types of questions each explained by James May and there are seventy of them in total.

description:
Derby Day is a casual family horse racing game for up to four players.

The DVD game contains eight simulated horse races. The game does nothing other than show the horse races so one player has to take the role of bookmaker. The bookie gives every player 100,000 in starting money, takes the bets before each race and pays out any cash when the race is over. Betting in this game is simplified, players can bet on a horse to win or to place -i.e. finish second or third. If a horse comes last anyone who bet on that horse gets their money back. Players can bet on up to three horses in a race.

Though the races are fully voiced with an enthusiastic Australian commentator the DVD itself has neither instructions not a tutorial so before the game can start each player must read the rules or have the rules explained to them by someone who has read the instructions.
Once past the title screen the game immediately starts showing the horses in the paddock in the pre-race parade with the commentator introducing each one and giving the betting odds. When all the horses have been introduced the game pauses giving the players time to place their bets, when all transactions have been completed a player presses START on the remote controller and the race begins. Each race takes about a minute to run.
After the race the game displays the names and odds of the horses placed first, second, third and last and it stays on this screen giving the bookmaker time to settle up.
The game continues through eight races and the player with the most money wins

description:
Family Fortunes: Hosted By Vernon Kaye is a DVD game based on a popular UK television show and this is the the third UK DVD title that uses its format.

Just like the show this game has five rounds and is made for two teams. In a round each team is asked a question in turn and their aim is to give the same top five answers that the public gave when they were asked the same question. Each answer scores points depending on the percentage of the public who gave the same answer. If a team gives a single wrong answer their opponents get a chance to 'steal' the points earned so far.

The game which does NOT keep score for the players, instead a score pad is provided so that teams can write down their own scores.

Round One is always directed at Team A who have thirty seconds to write down what they consider to be the top five answers; during those thirty seconds Team B must write down a single answer in the STEAL section of their score sheet. When the time is up the players reveal the correct answers one at a time and Team A score points for every correct answer they have no matter what order they wrote they were written down. The number of points scored for a correct answer, as in the TV show, depends on the number of people in the survey who gave that answer. If Team A give five correct answers then they win the round, and the points, outright.
If an answer appears which Team A did not write down then Team B have a chance to steal the points, for this to happen Team B's answer must be among the remaining answers the public gave to the question.

Once Team A has finished its turn it is Team B’s turn.

Round Two is the "Viewer’s Question" round. Here both teams play and have just fifteen seconds to write down three answers. Either, both or neither team can score fifty points if one of their three answers matches the top answer from the public survey.

Round Three is a replay of Round One.

Round Four is the "Double Money" round, this is also a replay of Round One but, obviously, the points that can be scored or stolen are higher.

Round Five is the "Big Money" round where each team selects their strongest player to play against the opposing team’s candidate and answer five questions in 25 seconds. When time is up, the answers are revealed and if either player’s answer matches the survey’s answer that player wins more points to be added to their team’s total.

description:
Now That's What I Call a Family Quiz is a quiz based on pop music from the 1960's through to the 2000's. It is played bu either a single player/team or by two players/teams going head to head. The game keeps track of the score so there is no need for pencils and paper.

The aim of the game is to start as a nobody and build a music career, to do this the player(s) answer music questions and with each correct answer their career progresses. There are twenty steps along the career path starting with "Buying a guitar"; "Joining a band"; "Writing a song"; all the way to playing a stadium gig.

To play a 'Head to Head' game the players select one of the specialty decades from the 60's through to the 00's, during the game the team will receive more questions on this decade that the others. The game then begins, for each correct answer the team moves along their career path towards stardom but control passes to the opposing team if a question is answered incorrectly.
If a team answers two questions correctly then the third question will be from their chosen decade and if that is answered correctly the player/team advances a further two places along their career path. Control always passes to the opposing team after the third question.
The game will not allow two teams to occupy the same place on the career ladder. Should this happen at the end of a round then there is a Generation Clash question in which the first team to identify a song or a group and shout out the answer wins.

A single player game is almost exactly the same as the 'Head to Head' game the difference being with the final question of each round. If the third question is answered correctly the player advanced two places as before but if it is answered incorrectly the player drops back two spaces.

There is no host for this game so nothing is explained verbally. The instructions on how to play are a series of text screens, the questions are screens with multiple choice answers and the tasks are also presented as screens of text.
